Question: Did Bill Clinton enter polling places on Super Tuesday, and what evidence supports this?

Prediction.reasoning: The question seeks confirmation of Bill Clinton's actions on Super Tuesday, which might not be completely covered in the available information. An online search can provide recent news articles or official reports on any claims of election law violations by Bill Clinton.

Query1.query: Did Bill Clinton violate election laws Super Tuesday?

Query1.title: People are not happy about Bill Clinton's appearance at Mass. polls ...
Query1.snippet: Mar 2, 2016 ... After the state alerted the campaign about election rules in Mass., the former president attended a rally in New Bedford.

content.content:

Sanders narrowly lost to Hillary Clinton in the state primaries on Super Tuesday.
Advertisement
* * *
* * *
In a statement, Mitchell said the polling place in Buttonwood Park remained open at all times, and that “no orders were given to restrict access at any location.”
“At no time did former President Clinton enter a polling location in New Bedford,” he added.
Clinton’s appearance in New Bedford came after he had already been criticized earlier in the day for his actions at two polling places in the Boston area.
While stumping for his wife, Clinton entered polling stations at the , and the , in Newton.
The incidents prompted Galvin’s office to reach out to Hillary Clinton’s campaign and remind them of the rules barring solicitation of votes near polling places.
“He had the right to go into the polling locations, and say ‘Hello’ to workers who were there. The issue is, you can’t go inside and say, ‘Vote for my wife,’ or ‘Vote for Hillary,’” Galvin said in a telephone interview Wednesday.
Galvin said that in New Bedford, the former president did speak in front of the polling location, but Galvin didn’t know how close he was.
Galvin said that his office was “annoyed” that Clinton addressed hundreds of people during an “ad hoc” rally near a polling place, after his wife’s campaign had already been contacted several times. But allegations that Clinton kept people from actually voting in the election, Galvin said, are erroneous.
“It’s unusual to have someone outside having a rally, that’s for sure,” Galvin said. “But voting was never interrupted, and voters could always get access to the polls”
Galvin said his office is not “investigating” Clinton’s conduct, but rather, his office wants to look at ways to make sure that, in the future, candidates' supporters don’t cause traffic jams or hinder access to voting locations.
Advertisement
* * *
* * *
“There was a traffic issue, there is no disputing that — it should have been organized away from the polls,” Galvin said. “It definitely made it more difficult for voters to park — that I don’t dispute — but the voting was never disrupted.”
Peter Ubertaccio, a political science professor at Stonehill College, said that Clinton’s staff should have taken “much better care to ensure he didn’t do anything that was viewed as disruptive.” But at this point, he said, it’s not likely that much can be done.
“Not every violation needs to result in some sort of...[Content truncated]

It has a long history of investigative journalism and covers a wide range of topics, including local, national, and international news. The Globe has garnered several awards for its reporting and is seen as a trusted source, which strengthens its credibility significantly.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence describes Bill Clinton’s presence at polling places and how it attracted attention. It provides insight into the concerns raised by state officials regarding election rules and the resulting confusion over whether he was violating any laws. The mention of interactions at polling locations further supports the question regarding his presence at such locations.

Query1.title: President Bill Clinton greets Super Tuesday voters at West Roxbury ...
Query1.snippet: Mar 1, 2016 ... WEST ROXBURY - At 9:35 a.m., as a steady stream of voters headed into Holy Name Church gymnasium to vote, former President Bill Clinton ...

content.content:
WEST ROXBURY - At 9:35 a.m., as a steady stream of voters headed into Holy Name Church gymnasium to vote, former President Bill Clinton arrived in an SUV.
He waved, he shook hands, he posed for pictures, he kissed an old lady on the top of her head.
One man was overheard exclaiming, "I just bumped into the president. It was awesome!"
Clinton, the former president and the husband of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, is spending Tuesday morning in Massachusetts, visiting four polling places in the eastern part of the state. He also held a late-night rally in Worcester on Monday.
Massachusetts is one of more than a dozen states holding a presidential primary or caucus on Super Tuesday, and it is home to one of the tightest contests on the Democratic side, where Hillary Clinton is running against Vermont U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders.
"It's great to see the attention here in Boston and Massachusetts," said Boston Mayor Marty Walsh. "I think that people aren't taking it for granted. Certainly, President Clinton being here today says a lot on Election Day. He could be in any state in the country, and he's here in Massachusetts."
Clinton spent 45 minutes at the polling place in West Roxbury, his first stop of the day. He did not take press questions, but spent the time shaking hands, chatting with...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: MassLive.com is a news website providing coverage primarily of events and news in Massachusetts. It is published by the Springfield Republican and offers a variety of local news reporting but has faced criticism for clickbait headlines and sensationalism at times. While generally reliable, it may not always meet the high standards of more esteemed newspapers, warranting a medium score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: The evidence documents Bill Clinton’s direct engagement with voters at a polling place, confirming that he entered a polling location on Super Tuesday. It provides specific details about his actions and the context of his visit, which is central to verifying the claim being questioned.

Query1.title: More than 45K sign petition to arrest Bill Clinton
Query1.snippet: Mar 2, 2016 ... A petition calling for the arrest and prosecution of former President Bill Clinton alleges he violated Massachusetts election laws.

  More than 45,000 people have signed a petition calling for the arrest  and prosecution of former President Bill Clinton for what they alleged were violations of Massachusetts election laws — even though state officials have said he acted legally.
  Leading up to his wife's victory over U.S. Sen Bernie Sanders of Vermont in the  Massachusetts primary on Tuesday, the former president went  inside a polling station in Boston, according to multiple  reports. Hillary  Clinton, a former secretary of state and senator, won by  about 17,000 votes, according to NBC News.
  Bill Clinton talked with poll workers and took a photo with a  woman at the Holy Name Parish School's gymnasium in West Roxbury,The Boston Globe  reported, citing press pool reports. The petition,  posted on Change.org, charges that Bill Clinton made a "clear,  knowing and egregious violation of the campaign laws to swing an  election in a significant way."
He also entered a polling station in Newton and attended an event outside of a polling location in New Bedford, according to the Globe.
  A legal summary from the Massachusetts secretary of state says that on  election day, "certain activities are prohibited within the  polling location and within 150 feet of the polling place."
  "A person standing within 150 feet of a polling location,  including observers in the polling location, may not: hold any  campaign sign; hand any person literature intended to influence  the voter's action at the polls; wear any campaign buttons or  identifying signage; solicit a person's vote for or against a  candidate or question on the ballot; or, distribute stickers,"  the document says.
  Despite no report of the former president explicitly asking  voters to support his wife, the online petition alleges he was  "electioneering within the boundary."
Perhaps indicating where signatories' sympathies lie, the top voted  comment...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: CNBC is a major news outlet focusing on business news, finance, and economic matters. While it has credibility in financial reporting, it has been critiqued for sensationalism in its coverage of other topics. However, its standards for reporting on financial regulations and markets make it a reliable source, maintaining a solid reputation overall.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: The evidence discusses a petition calling for Clinton’s arrest based on alleged violations of election laws, confirming that he was indeed at polling locations. It mentions that he interacted with voters, contributing to the understanding of the context and controversy surrounding his presence.

QA.Question: Did Bill Clinton enter polling places on Super Tuesday, and what evidence supports this?
QA.Answer:
Yes, Bill Clinton did enter polling places on Super Tuesday. Evidence supporting this claim includes reports indicating that he visited several polling locations in Massachusetts while campaigning for his wife, Hillary Clinton.

1. According to a Boston Globe article, during Super Tuesday, Bill Clinton entered polling stations in Newton, Massachusetts, while campaigning, which led to some concern about the respect of election laws. The article states that while he could greet election workers, he wasn't allowed to solicit votes within the polling locations. This implies that he did enter these polling places during his visit [Query 1_evidence_1].

2. Similarly, a report from MassLive confirms that Bill Clinton spent time at multiple polling places on Super Tuesday, including Holy Name Church gymnasium in West Roxbury. The article describes him greeting voters, shaking hands, and taking pictures as he made his rounds, which further supports the claim that he entered polling areas [Query 2_evidence_1].

Taken together, the evidence strongly suggests that Bill Clinton did enter polling places on Super Tuesday while engaging with voters.
